@mdavidallen Despicable people work their way downward through platforms until you are preaching to your 25 devoted followers in a secret encrypted Telegram channel. But I am glad that is how the internet works, because I fear how censorship created for 8chan would affect free speech later

@mdavidallen I think I am arguing exactly the opposite. 8chan was successful because it was central and well-known, itself fractured and radicalized from a central and well-known gathering place. It gets smaller as it is fractured. But I am glad there are mechanisms for fracture vs erasure
Tl;dr hard cases make bad law

The benefits of a federated system, like the internet, are that while I trust no individual to make the right decisions 100% of the time, I trust the hivemind of globally dispersed administrators to coalesce. If you somehow piss them all off individually you have truly fucked up

We need to be cognizant of the fact any technological response to despicable people on 8chan could then be turned around and deployed on content that certain people don‚Äôt want discussed, like the actions of ICE / CBP on the border, or organizing of BLM protests.

As long as it is private companies themselves choosing to disassociate with despicable people, and not governments, I think driving these people to deeper and darker corners of the web makes the world better. Does it fix the problem? No. Does it reduce the symptoms? I think yes.

The internet‚Äôs ability to keep information from being censored is one of its most important features. I did not really believe in the effectiveness of deplatforming until I saw what happened with Milo. https://t.co/uNZwmyoBfJ

When approaching problems, a typical engineering approach is to find a simple solution. Like drilling a hole through a wall. 

My favorite solutions, though, are more like water. Finding the cracks, the natural pathways, and moving through those and widening them- soaking through
